b: Math formulas that describe how an object moves over time, like predicting where a golf ball will go.
i: Differential equations relating position, velocity, acceleration, and forces acting on a system.
a: Newton-Euler or Lagrangian formulations yielding ODEs: M(q)q̈ + C(q,q̇)q̇ + g(q) = τ.

b: A way to describe motion using energy instead of forces, often simpler for complex systems like the human body.
i: Formulation based on L = T - V (kinetic minus potential energy), yielding equations of motion via the Euler-Lagrange equation.

b: Another way to describe motion using total energy, useful for understanding energy conservation in movement.
i: Reformulation of dynamics using generalized momenta p and coordinates q, with H = T + V representing total energy.

b: A step-by-step method for calculating forces in linked body segments, working from the extremities inward.
i: Recursive algorithm computing forces and torques by sweeping outward for kinematics then inward for dynamics. O(n) complexity.

b: A key formula that derives motion equations from energy descriptions of a system.
i: d/dt(∂L/∂q̇) - ∂L/∂q = Q, where L is the Lagrangian and Q represents non-conservative generalized forces.

b: A numerical recipe for advancing a simulation forward in time with good accuracy.
i: Family of ODE integrators using weighted slope evaluations. RK4 (4th-order) balances accuracy and cost for biomechanics simulations.

b: A time-stepping method that conserves energy well over long simulations, important for physics accuracy.
i: Semi-implicit integrator that updates velocity then position, preserving the symplectic structure and long-term energy behavior.

b: A table of numbers describing how heavy and how the mass is distributed across all body segments.
i: Symmetric positive-definite matrix M(q) mapping generalized accelerations to generalized forces in the equations of motion.

b: A force that appears when things move within a rotating system, like the club moving relative to rotating arms.
i: Velocity-dependent force in rotating frames, captured by the C(q,q̇) term in the equations of motion.

b: The outward pull you feel on a merry-go-round, or the club pulling away from you during a swing.
i: Apparent outward force in rotating reference frames, proportional to mass, angular velocity squared, and radius.

b: The downward pull of gravity on every part of the body and club during a swing.
i: Configuration-dependent gravitational force vector g(q) in the equations of motion, pointing along the global -Z axis.

b: Forces that keep things connected, like the force keeping your hand attached to the club grip.
i: Reaction forces enforcing kinematic constraints (joint connections, ground contact). They do no virtual work in ideal constraints.

b: Forces that arise when two objects touch, like your feet pushing on the ground or hands gripping the club.
i: Normal and frictional forces at contact points, computed via complementarity conditions or penalty methods in simulation.

b: The force that prevents sliding, like the grip between your shoes and the ground during a swing.
i: Tangential contact force opposing relative sliding. Coulomb model: |f_t| ≤ μ|f_n|, where μ is the friction coefficient.

b: The push-back force perpendicular to a surface, like the ground pushing up on your feet.
i: Component of contact force perpendicular to the contact surface, preventing interpenetration of bodies.

b: The total push delivered over a short time, like the brief but powerful force at club-ball impact.
i: Time integral of force: J = ∫F dt. Equals the change in momentum. Critical for impact analysis in golf.

b: A measure of how hard it is to stop something moving, combining mass and speed.
i: Product of mass and velocity: p = mv. Conserved in isolated systems. Transfer of momentum drives ball launch.

b: The rotational equivalent of momentum, measuring how strongly something spins.
i: L = Iω for rigid bodies. In golf, angular momentum transfers sequentially through the kinetic chain from hips to club.

b: The energy of motion. A faster-moving club has more kinetic energy to transfer to the ball.
i: Energy due to motion: T = ½mv² (translational) + ½Iω² (rotational). Key metric for swing power output.

b: Stored energy due to position, like the energy stored at the top of the backswing due to height and stretched muscles.
i: Energy stored in gravitational field (mgh) or elastic elements (muscles, tendons). Converts to kinetic energy during downswing.

b: The principle that the work done on an object equals its change in kinetic energy.
i: W_net = ΔKE. In golf, net work from muscles and gravity determines final club head kinetic energy at impact.

b: An object that doesn't bend or deform, used to simplify body segment modeling.
i: Idealized body where distance between any two points remains constant. Standard assumption for skeletal segments in biomechanics.

b: An object that can bend, stretch, or compress, like muscles and soft tissue.
i: Body whose shape changes under load. Relevant for modeling club shaft flex, muscle tissue, and soft-tissue artifacts.

b: A system of connected rigid parts, like the linked segments of a human body.
i: Collection of rigid bodies connected by joints with defined degrees of freedom. The golfer + club is a multibody system with ~30 DOF.

b: The number of independent ways something can move, like bending, rotating, or sliding.
i: Minimum number of independent coordinates needed to describe a system's configuration. Human body: ~200 DOF; golf model: ~30 DOF.

b: A set of numbers that fully describes the position of every part of a system.
i: Minimal set of independent coordinates q describing system configuration. For articulated bodies, these are typically joint angles.

b: Forces expressed in terms of joint movements rather than simple pushes and pulls.
i: Forces/torques conjugate to generalized coordinates: τ = M(q)q̈ + C + g. Include muscle torques and external loads.

b: A thought experiment about tiny imaginary displacements used to derive motion equations.
i: Work done by forces through infinitesimal virtual displacements consistent with constraints. Foundation of Lagrangian mechanics.

b: A rule that converts dynamics problems into static-like problems by adding inertial forces.
i: States that F - ma = 0 for virtual displacements, bridging Newton's laws and analytical mechanics via virtual work.

b: A restriction on movement that depends only on position, like a hinge that only allows rotation.
i: Constraint expressible as f(q,t) = 0, depending only on coordinates and time. Joint constraints are typically holonomic.

b: A restriction that depends on velocity, like rolling without slipping.
i: Constraint involving velocities that cannot be integrated to a position constraint: f(q,q̇,t) = 0. Rolling contact is a common example.

b: Whether a system returns to its original state after being disturbed, like maintaining balance during a swing.
i: A system is stable if small perturbations produce bounded responses. Lyapunov stability analysis quantifies this for dynamic systems.

b: A balanced state where all forces cancel out and there is no net motion.
i: State where net force and torque are zero. Static equilibrium (no motion) vs dynamic equilibrium (constant velocity).

b: The gradual loss of motion energy, like how a pendulum eventually stops swinging.
i: Energy dissipation opposing motion, modeled as force proportional to velocity: F = -bv. Muscles and joints have natural damping properties.

b: A description of how mass is distributed in 3D, affecting how an object resists rotation.
i: 3x3 symmetric matrix I describing rotational inertia about all axes. Diagonal elements are moments of inertia; off-diagonal are products of inertia.

b: Where something is in space, described by coordinates like (x, y, z).
i: Location of a point in a reference frame, expressed as a 3D vector. Tracked over time to compute velocity and acceleration.

b: How fast and in which direction something is moving.
i: Time derivative of position: v = dx/dt. Club head velocity at impact is the primary driver of ball speed.

b: How quickly speed or direction changes, like the rapid speed increase during the downswing.
i: Time derivative of velocity: a = dv/dt. Measured by accelerometers or computed from position data via double differentiation.

b: How fast something rotates, like the spin rate of the club or a body segment.
i: Rate of change of orientation: ω = dθ/dt. Expressed as a 3D vector whose direction is the rotation axis.

b: How quickly rotation speed changes, crucial during the golf swing transition.
i: Time derivative of angular velocity: α = dω/dt. Drives joint torque requirements via Newton's second law for rotation.

b: A 3x3 grid of numbers that describes how one coordinate frame is rotated relative to another.
i: Orthogonal matrix R ∈ SO(3) mapping vectors between coordinate frames. Used to transform forces and positions between body segments.

b: Three rotation angles describing orientation, like tilting, turning, and leaning of body segments.
i: Three sequential rotations (e.g., ZYX convention) defining orientation. Intuitive but suffer from gimbal lock at certain configurations.

b: A mathematical tool for describing rotations without the problems that Euler angles can have.
i: 4D number q = (w, x, y, z) representing rotation. Avoids gimbal lock and provides smooth interpolation (SLERP) between orientations.

b: A single matrix combining rotation and position to describe where and how a body segment is oriented.
i: 4x4 matrix combining rotation R and translation t into a single transformation. Chain multiplication gives end-effector pose.

b: A standard way to describe the geometry of linked segments, widely used in robotics and biomechanics.
i: Convention using 4 parameters per joint (θ, d, a, α) to define transformations between consecutive links in a kinematic chain.

b: Calculating where the club head ends up given all the joint angles in the body.
i: Computing end-effector (club head) pose from joint angles by chaining transformations along the kinematic chain.

b: Figuring out what joint angles are needed to place the club head at a desired position.
i: Solving for joint angles q given desired end-effector pose. Generally non-unique and may use iterative methods or pseudoinverse solutions.

b: A matrix that relates joint movements to club head movement, showing how each joint contributes.
i: Matrix J mapping joint velocities to end-effector velocity: v = J(q)q̇. Rows correspond to task-space DOFs, columns to joint DOFs.

b: The region of space that the club head or hand can reach given the body's joint ranges.
i: Set of all achievable end-effector positions/orientations. Dexterous workspace requires full orientation control.

b: A body configuration where certain movements become impossible, like a fully extended arm losing a bending direction.
i: Configuration where the Jacobian loses rank, reducing achievable task-space velocities. Near-singular configurations amplify torque requirements.

b: The angle at a body joint, like how much the elbow is bent or the hip is rotated.
i: Angular measure of relative orientation between two connected segments. Primary generalized coordinate for revolute joints.

b: How far a joint can move, from fully bent to fully straight or fully rotated.
i: Angular extent of joint movement in each plane. Limited by bone geometry, ligaments, and muscle flexibility. Varies by individual.

b: The path an object follows through space over time, like the club head path during a swing.
i: Time-parameterized curve q(t) describing motion through configuration or task space. Analyzed for smoothness and optimality.

b: Computing an efficient movement path from one position to another while avoiding obstacles.
i: Finding a collision-free trajectory in configuration space. In biomechanics, the body naturally optimizes movement paths.

b: Creating smooth curves through measured data points to fill in gaps between measurements.
i: Piecewise polynomial (cubic or quintic) fitting through waypoints with continuity constraints. Used to smooth motion capture data.

b: The complete position and orientation of a body or object in 3D space.
i: Combined position (3D translation) and orientation (3D rotation) of a rigid body, requiring 6 parameters (SE(3) element).

b: Which direction something is pointing or how it is rotated.
i: Rotational component of pose, represented by rotation matrices, Euler angles, or quaternions. Three degrees of freedom.

b: Movement from one place to another without rotating.
i: Linear displacement vector in 3D space. Three degrees of freedom (x, y, z).

b: A combined rotation and slide along the same axis, like a corkscrew motion.
i: General rigid body displacement as simultaneous rotation about and translation along a screw axis. Basis of screw theory kinematics.

b: A combined description of linear and angular velocity of a rigid body.
i: 6D velocity vector combining angular and linear velocity: ξ = (ω, v). Element of se(3), the Lie algebra of SE(3).

b: A combined description of force and torque acting on a body.
i: 6D force vector combining torque and force: w = (τ, f). Dual to twist. Used for ground reaction force analysis.

b: The velocity of a body expressed in a fixed reference frame rather than the body's own frame.
i: Twist expressed in the spatial (world) frame. Distinguished from body velocity which is expressed in the body frame.

b: A coordinate system attached to and moving with a body segment.
i: Local reference frame fixed to a rigid body. Velocities and forces can be expressed in body or spatial frames.

b: The fixed, non-moving coordinate system used as the main reference for all measurements.
i: Global inertial reference frame. Typically Z-up with origin at ground level. All body frames are expressed relative to it.

b: The set of all possible body positions described by joint angles.
i: n-dimensional space of all generalized coordinates q. Each point represents a unique system configuration. Abbreviated C-space.

b: The study of how people walk and move, used to detect problems or improve performance.
i: Systematic measurement and analysis of locomotion using kinematics, kinetics, and EMG. Methods transfer to golf swing analysis.

b: The distance covered in one complete walking or running cycle.
i: Distance between successive contacts of the same foot. Normalized by leg length for inter-subject comparison.

b: The rhythm or rate of steps during walking, or swing tempo in golf.
i: Number of steps per minute in gait, or swings per unit time. Optimal cadence minimizes energy cost for a given speed.

b: The part of the gait cycle when the foot is on the ground, similar to the grounded phase of a golf swing.
i: Portion of gait cycle from heel strike to toe-off (~60% of cycle). Ground reaction forces are generated only during stance.

b: The part of a gait cycle when the foot is in the air between steps.
i: Portion of gait cycle from toe-off to heel strike (~40% of cycle). Leg moves as a pendulum under gravity and muscle control.

b: When both feet are on the ground at the same time during walking.
i: Period when both feet contact the ground simultaneously. Decreases with walking speed and disappears during running.

b: One complete sequence of steps, from one heel strike to the next heel strike of the same foot.
i: Full locomotion cycle divided into stance and swing phases. Provides the temporal framework for normalizing kinematic and kinetic data.

b: The net rotational force at a joint, representing the combined effect of muscles, ligaments, and other structures.
i: Net torque about a joint axis calculated via inverse dynamics. Represents the resultant of all internal structures crossing the joint.

b: How a body segment resists changes in rotation, depending on its mass and shape.
i: Rotational inertia of a body segment about its center of mass. Determined from anthropometric data or medical imaging.

b: Measurements of body parts (mass, length, center of mass) needed for biomechanical calculations.
i: Mass, length, center of mass location, and moments of inertia for each segment. Estimated from regression equations or imaging.

b: Measuring the human body's dimensions and proportions for biomechanical analysis.
i: Systematic measurement of body dimensions. Used to estimate segment inertial properties via regression models (de Leva, Dempster).

b: The balance point of a body or segment where all mass effectively concentrates.
i: Point where total mass can be considered concentrated for translational dynamics. Whole-body COM tracked for balance analysis.

b: The point where gravity appears to act on the body, same as center of mass in uniform gravity.
i: Point where gravitational force effectively acts. Coincides with center of mass in uniform gravity fields on Earth.

b: How much a body segment resists spinning, depending on mass and how far the mass is from the rotation axis.
i: Scalar I = ∑mr² for a given axis. Larger for extended limbs (backswing) vs tucked positions. Governs angular acceleration.

b: A formula for calculating rotational inertia about any axis from the inertia about the center of mass.
i: I_axis = I_cm + md², where d is the distance between axes. Essential for computing segment inertias about joint centers.

b: Expressing forces as multiples of body weight so you can compare people of different sizes.
i: Dividing forces by body weight (mg) to enable inter-subject comparison. GRF is typically reported in BW units.

b: A technique for measuring muscle electrical activity to see when and how hard muscles are working.
i: Recording of muscle electrical signals via surface or intramuscular electrodes. Indicates muscle activation timing and relative intensity.

b: How much a muscle is turned on, from completely relaxed to fully contracted.
i: Neural drive level to a muscle, from 0 (inactive) to 1 (maximal). Estimated from processed EMG or computed via optimization.

b: The principle that muscles produce less force when contracting quickly and more force when moving slowly.
i: Hyperbolic relationship (Hill equation): faster shortening reduces force capacity. Eccentric contractions exceed isometric force.

b: The principle that muscles produce the most force at an optimal length, less when too short or too stretched.
i: Parabolic relationship between muscle fiber length and isometric force. Peak at optimal sarcomere length (~2.7 μm in humans).

b: A simplified model of muscle behavior using three components: contractile element, elastic springs, and dampers.
i: Lumped-parameter model: contractile element (CE) + series elastic (SE) + parallel elastic (PE). Standard in musculoskeletal simulation.

b: The combination of a muscle and its connecting tendon, working together to produce and transmit force.
i: Functional unit of muscle fiber and tendon in series. Tendon stores elastic energy during stretch-shortening cycles.

b: A muscle contraction where the muscle generates force but doesn't change length, like holding a heavy object still.
i: Contraction at constant muscle length. Produces maximum force at optimal length. Used as reference for normalizing force capacity.

b: A muscle contraction where the force stays constant while the muscle shortens or lengthens.
i: Contraction against constant load. Includes concentric (shortening) and eccentric (lengthening) phases.

b: A muscle contraction at a constant speed, often measured with special testing machines.
i: Contraction at constant angular velocity, achieved using dynamometer machines that adapt resistance. Used for strength testing.

b: When a muscle shortens while producing force, like the bicep during a curl.
i: Shortening contraction where muscle force exceeds external load. Force decreases with increasing shortening velocity.

b: When a muscle lengthens while producing force, like lowering a weight slowly. Produces more force than shortening.
i: Lengthening contraction where external load exceeds muscle force. Can produce ~1.5x isometric force. Important for deceleration phases.

b: The main muscle responsible for a movement, like the pectorals during a golf downswing.
i: Primary mover for a given joint action. Produces the torque that drives the intended motion.

b: The muscle opposing the main mover, providing control and braking during fast movements.
i: Muscle opposing the agonist. Co-activation with agonist increases joint stiffness and control accuracy.

b: A helper muscle that assists the main mover in producing a movement.
i: Muscle assisting the agonist or stabilizing adjacent joints. Multiple synergists provide redundant control strategies.

b: When opposing muscles activate simultaneously to stiffen and stabilize a joint.
i: Simultaneous activation of agonist and antagonist muscles. Increases joint stiffness at the cost of metabolic efficiency.

b: A natural movement pattern where a muscle stretches then rapidly shortens, producing more power than shortening alone.
i: Eccentric-concentric muscle action sequence that enhances force via elastic energy storage and stretch reflex. Key in golf downswing.

b: Explosive exercises using the stretch-shortening cycle, like jumping, to build power.
i: Training method exploiting SSC to maximize power output. Short amortization phase between eccentric and concentric phases is critical.

b: Your body's sense of where its parts are and how they are moving without looking.
i: Sensory information from muscle spindles, GTOs, and joint receptors about body position and movement. Essential for motor control.

b: The process of improving movement skills through practice, like developing a consistent golf swing.
i: Relatively permanent changes in motor behavior through practice. Progresses from cognitive to associative to autonomous stages.

b: How fast the club is moving at impact. Faster speed generally means more distance.
i: Velocity of the club head at impact, the primary determinant of ball speed. PGA Tour average: ~113 mph (driver).

b: How fast the golf ball leaves the club face after impact.
i: Initial velocity of the ball post-impact. Related to club head speed via smash factor. PGA avg: ~167 mph (driver).

b: The efficiency of energy transfer from club to ball. Higher means better contact quality.
i: Ratio of ball speed to club head speed. Maximum ~1.50 for driver. Indicates quality of impact (center hit vs off-center).

b: The angle at which the ball takes off relative to the ground.
i: Vertical angle of ball trajectory at launch. Determined by dynamic loft and attack angle. Optimal varies by club and speed.

b: How fast the ball is spinning after being hit. Affects how high the ball flies and how it stops on the green.
i: Angular velocity of the ball post-impact. Backspin creates lift; sidespin causes curve. Optimal driver: ~2200-2800 rpm.

b: How far the ball flies through the air before landing.
i: Aerial distance from launch to landing. Function of ball speed, launch angle, spin rate, and atmospheric conditions.

b: The complete distance the ball travels including carry and roll after landing.
i: Carry distance plus roll. Roll depends on landing angle, spin, and ground conditions.

b: Whether the club is moving up or down when it hits the ball. Drivers hit up; irons hit down.
i: Vertical angle of club head path at impact. Positive = ascending (driver: +3-5°). Negative = descending (irons: -2 to -6°).

b: The direction the club is moving at impact relative to the target line, affecting ball curve.
i: Horizontal direction of club head travel at impact. Positive = in-to-out; negative = out-to-in. Interacts with face angle to determine spin axis.

b: Where the club face is pointing at impact. Determines the initial direction the ball starts.
i: Orientation of club face at impact relative to target line. Primary determinant of initial ball direction (~75-85% influence).

b: The actual loft angle of the club at the moment of impact, which may differ from the club's built-in loft.
i: Effective loft at impact after accounting for shaft lean, wrist conditions, and attack angle. Determines launch and spin.

b: The tilt of the ball's spin axis, determining whether it curves left or right in flight.
i: Tilt of the ball's rotation axis from vertical. Result of face-to-path difference at impact. 0° = pure backspin.

b: The backward spin on the ball that makes it rise in the air and stop quickly on the green.
i: Spin component about the horizontal axis perpendicular to the ball's direction. Creates aerodynamic lift via the Magnus effect.

b: The sideways spin that makes the ball curve left or right during flight.
i: Horizontal component of ball spin resulting from a tilted spin axis. Creates a lateral Magnus force causing draw or fade.

b: The ideal spot on the club face to hit the ball for maximum energy transfer and best feel.
i: Point on the club face aligned with the center of mass, minimizing twisting at impact. Produces maximum smash factor.

b: How resistant the club head is to twisting on off-center hits. Higher MOI means more forgiveness.
i: Rotational inertia of the club head about its center of mass. Higher MOI reduces speed loss and directional error on mishits.

b: How much the club shaft bends during the swing, affecting timing and feel.
i: Stiffness rating of the shaft (L, A, R, S, X). Flex profile affects loading/unloading timing and dynamic loft at impact.

b: The point on the shaft that bends the most, influencing launch angle and feel.
i: Location of maximum shaft deflection. Low kick point increases dynamic loft; high kick point reduces it.

b: The rhythm and timing of the swing, measured as the ratio of backswing to downswing time.
i: Ratio of backswing to downswing duration. Elite golfers average ~3:1 ratio regardless of overall swing speed.

b: The tilted circular path the club follows during the swing, like a tilted wheel.
i: Inclined plane best fitting the club head trajectory. Analyzed via SVD/PCA fit. Deviations indicate compensatory patterns.

b: The angle between the shaft and the ground at address, affecting where the ball goes.
i: Angle between the shaft axis and the ground plane when the sole sits flat. Incorrect lie angle causes directional bias.

b: The hinging of the wrists during the backswing that stores energy for the downswing.
i: Radial deviation (cocking) of the wrists creating a lever angle between forearm and club. Maximum at top of backswing.

b: The uncocking of the wrists during the downswing, adding speed to the club head.
i: Rapid ulnar deviation and uncocking of wrists releasing stored energy. Timing relative to impact is critical for consistency.

b: The angle between the club and the lead arm during the downswing. Maintaining lag creates more speed.
i: Angle between club shaft and lead forearm during downswing. Late release (more lag) correlates with higher club head speed.

b: Rotating the forearm so the palm faces up, important in the release phase of the golf swing.
i: Forearm rotation moving the palm toward supine (upward) position. Lead arm supination through impact squares the club face.

b: Rotating the forearm so the palm faces down, the opposite of supination.
i: Forearm rotation moving the palm toward prone (downward) position. Trail arm pronation helps close the face through impact.

b: The turning of the hips during the swing, generating power from the ground up.
i: Axial rotation of the pelvis. Leads the kinetic chain in the downswing. Peak velocity of ~720°/s in elite golfers.

b: The turning of the shoulders during the swing, following the hips in the power sequence.
i: Thorax axial rotation relative to global frame. Lags behind hip rotation, creating the X-factor stretch for energy storage.

b: The forward or backward tilting of the pelvis during the swing, affecting posture and power.
i: Sagittal-plane inclination of the pelvis. Anterior tilt increases lumbar lordosis. Changes through the swing phases.

b: The forward bend angle of the spine at address and throughout the swing.
i: Sagittal flexion angle of the trunk. Maintaining consistent spine angle is key for consistent contact. Changes indicate early extension.

b: The golfer's setup position before starting the swing.
i: Static posture at swing initiation. Defines initial joint angles, stance width, ball position, and weight distribution.

b: The first part of the swing where the club moves away from the ball to the top position.
i: Phase from address to top of swing. Stores elastic energy via trunk rotation and wrist cock. Duration ~0.8-1.0s for most golfers.

b: The powerful forward motion from the top of the swing to impact with the ball.
i: Phase from top of swing to impact. Duration ~0.2-0.3s. Kinetic chain sequence produces peak club head acceleration.

b: The brief moment when the club contacts the ball, lasting only about 0.5 milliseconds.
i: Club-ball contact event lasting ~0.45ms. Ball compresses, energy transfers. All launch conditions determined at this instant.

b: The continuation of the swing after hitting the ball, important for deceleration and injury prevention.
i: Post-impact phase where the body decelerates. Proper follow-through dissipates rotational energy safely across the kinetic chain.

b: The balanced end pose of the swing, reflecting overall swing quality.
i: Terminal swing posture. Balanced finish with weight on lead foot indicates proper deceleration and kinetic chain sequencing.

b: The brief moment between backswing and downswing where the body reverses direction.
i: Critical phase where lower body initiates the downswing while upper body completes the backswing, creating X-factor stretch.

b: The transfer of body weight from back foot to front foot during the downswing.
i: Center of pressure migration from trail to lead foot during downswing. Measured via dual force plates. Correlates with power generation.

b: The sideways bending of the spine during the swing, tilting away from or toward the target.
i: Frontal-plane trunk inclination. Increases toward trail side at top, reverses through impact. Excessive bend risks back injury.

b: A measure combining side bend and rotation speed that indicates spinal stress and injury risk.
i: Product of lateral bend angle and axial rotation velocity. Higher values indicate greater spinal loading and injury risk.

b: The small time increment used to advance a simulation, like frames in a movie.
i: Duration Δt between simulation steps. Smaller timesteps improve accuracy but increase computation. Typical: 0.001-0.01s for biomechanics.

b: Using math to step a simulation forward in time, computing new positions from current forces.
i: Approximating solutions of ODEs by discrete time-stepping. Choice of integrator affects accuracy, stability, and energy conservation.

b: The simplest method for stepping forward in time, fast but can become unstable.
i: First-order integrator: x(t+Δt) = x(t) + Δt·f(x,t). Conditionally stable; requires small timesteps for stiff systems.

b: A more stable but computationally expensive time-stepping method used for stiff problems.
i: Backward Euler: x(t+Δt) = x(t) + Δt·f(x(t+Δt),t+Δt). Unconditionally stable but adds numerical damping. Requires solving nonlinear system.

b: A balanced time-stepping method that is more stable than explicit Euler while being simpler than implicit methods.
i: Updates velocity explicitly then position with new velocity. Symplectic (energy-preserving). Default integrator in MuJoCo.

b: A time-stepping method that tracks position without explicitly computing velocity, good for particle systems.
i: Symplectic integrator: x(t+Δt) = 2x(t) - x(t-Δt) + a(t)Δt². Second-order accurate, time-reversible, energy-conserving.

b: A method where position and velocity updates alternate in half-steps, providing good energy conservation.
i: Symplectic integrator with velocity at half-steps. Equivalent to velocity Verlet. Used in molecular dynamics and n-body simulations.

b: A very accurate time-stepping method that evaluates the system four times per step.
i: Classic 4th-order method using weighted average of four slope evaluations. Local error O(Δt⁵). Gold standard for smooth ODE integration.

b: Automatically adjusting the time step size to be smaller when things change quickly and larger when they are smooth.
i: Timestep control based on error estimation. Pairs embedded methods (e.g., RK45) to estimate local error and adjust Δt accordingly.

b: Whether a simulation stays well-behaved or blows up due to mathematical errors accumulating over time.
i: Property that numerical errors remain bounded over time. Stiff systems require implicit methods or very small timesteps for stability.

b: Whether a simulation's results get closer to the true answer as you use smaller time steps.
i: Property that numerical solution approaches exact solution as Δt → 0. Order of convergence indicates the rate of improvement.

b: The process of figuring out when objects in a simulation touch or overlap.
i: Determining contact points and penetration depth between geometric primitives. Two phases: broad phase (AABB) and narrow phase (GJK/EPA).

b: A quick first pass to identify pairs of objects that might be touching, using simple bounding boxes.
i: Fast culling using axis-aligned bounding boxes (AABB) or spatial hashing. Reduces O(n²) pairs to a manageable subset for detailed checks.

b: A detailed check on object pairs that passed the broad phase to find exact contact points.
i: Precise contact detection using GJK/EPA algorithms on convex shapes or mesh-mesh intersection for complex geometry.

b: An efficient algorithm for determining if two convex shapes overlap.
i: Gilbert-Johnson-Keerthi algorithm uses Minkowski difference and simplex iteration to detect intersection between convex shapes in O(n) time.

b: The mathematical rules describing what happens when objects collide in a simulation.
i: Mathematical formulation for computing contact forces. Approaches include penalty methods (soft), complementarity (hard), and impulse-based.

b: A contact simulation approach that uses spring-like forces to push overlapping objects apart.
i: Soft contact model applying restoring force proportional to penetration depth. Simple to implement but requires stiffness tuning.

b: The algorithm that enforces physical rules like joints staying connected and objects not passing through each other.
i: Iterative solver enforcing equality and inequality constraints. Methods include PGS, Lemke, and direct factorization.

b: A mathematical formulation for contact that ensures objects either separate or have contact forces, not both.
i: Find z ≥ 0 such that w = Mz + q ≥ 0 and zᵀw = 0. Models unilateral contact constraints in rigid body dynamics.

b: A type of math problem where two quantities cannot both be positive at the same time.
i: Mathematical framework where for each pair (z_i, w_i), at least one must be zero. Generalizes LCP to nonlinear (NCP) and mixed (MCP) forms.

b: An iterative method for solving contact constraints one at a time, commonly used in physics engines.
i: Projected Gauss-Seidel (PGS): iteratively solves each contact constraint while projecting onto friction cone. Default in MuJoCo.

b: A method for solving equations by updating all unknowns simultaneously using previous values.
i: Updates all unknowns in parallel using previous iteration values. Slower convergence than Gauss-Seidel but naturally parallelizable.

b: A control method that plans ahead by simulating future outcomes to choose the best current action.
i: Online optimization solving a finite-horizon optimal control problem at each timestep. Handles constraints naturally.

b: Breaking a complex shape into many small pieces to analyze how forces spread through it.
i: Discretizing continuous domains into mesh elements to solve PDEs for stress, strain, and deformation. Used for club shaft and tissue modeling.

b: Rules that define what happens at the edges of a simulation, like a fixed support or applied force.
i: Constraints applied at domain boundaries: Dirichlet (fixed value) or Neumann (fixed gradient/flux). Essential for well-posed FEM problems.

b: Dividing a continuous shape into small triangles or boxes for computer simulation.
i: Converting continuous geometry into discrete elements (triangles, tetrahedra, hexahedra). Mesh quality affects solution accuracy.

b: A compact mathematical description of a system using position, velocity, and input variables.
i: Representation dx/dt = f(x,u) where x is the state vector and u is the control input. Foundation for modern control theory.

b: A plot showing both position and velocity of a system, revealing its complete dynamic behavior.
i: Space of all generalized coordinates and momenta (q, p). Trajectories in phase space fully describe system evolution. Cannot cross.

b: A sudden qualitative change in system behavior when a parameter is varied, like a tipping point.
i: Qualitative change in system dynamics as a parameter crosses a critical value. Types include saddle-node, Hopf, and period-doubling.

b: When tiny differences in starting conditions lead to vastly different outcomes, making long-term prediction impossible.
i: Deterministic but unpredictable behavior with sensitive dependence on initial conditions. Double pendulum is a classic example.

b: A platform embedded in the floor that measures the forces you push on the ground with during movement.
i: Instrumented platform with piezoelectric or strain gauge sensors measuring 3D ground reaction forces, moments, and center of pressure.

b: The single point on the ground where your total ground force effectively acts, like a balance point of pressure.
i: Point of application of the resultant GRF. COP = (M_y/F_z, -M_x/F_z). Trajectory indicates weight transfer patterns in the swing.

b: The twisting force the ground exerts on you around a vertical axis, related to rotational effort.
i: Vertical component of ground reaction moment (Mz), representing torque about the vertical axis. Indicates rotational demand of movement.

b: The rotational forces from the ground that resist or assist body rotation during movement.
i: 3D moment vector from force plate: (Mx, My, Mz). Combined with forces forms the full GRF wrench for biomechanical analysis.

b: A twisting or rotational force, like the turning force muscles apply at joints.
i: Rotational equivalent of force: τ = r × F. Causes angular acceleration proportional to moment of inertia: τ = Iα.

b: The complete set of forces and torques at a point, combining all linear and rotational forces.
i: 6D vector (force + torque) representing the full loading at a point. Used in GRF analysis and robotic force control.

b: Two equal and opposite forces that create pure rotation without moving the object sideways.
i: Pair of equal, opposite, non-collinear forces producing pure moment. Torque = F × d, independent of reference point.

b: The single force that represents the combined effect of all forces acting on an object.
i: Vector sum of all applied forces. If zero, the system is in translational equilibrium (Newton's first law).

b: The force that pushes back when you push on something, per Newton's third law.
i: Equal and opposite force arising from Newton's third law. Joint reaction forces act at articulation points between segments.

b: Forces within the body, like muscle tension or bone compression, that don't affect overall body motion.
i: Forces between components of the system (muscles, ligaments). Cancel in pairs for whole-body analysis but are critical for tissue loading.

b: Forces from outside the body, like gravity, ground reaction, and wind.
i: Forces applied to the system from outside: gravity, GRF, aerodynamic forces. Determine whole-body translational and rotational dynamics.

b: The pull of gravity on every body segment, always acting straight down.
i: F = mg acting at center of mass of each segment. The dominant external force in most biomechanical analyses.

b: The inward force that keeps something moving in a circle, like the pull on the club during a swing.
i: Force directed toward the center of circular motion: F = mv²/r = mω²r. Essential for maintaining the swing arc.

b: Air resistance that slows the golf ball down during flight.
i: Aerodynamic force opposing motion: F_d = ½C_dρAv². Depends on ball dimple pattern, speed, and air density.

b: The upward force created by backspin that keeps the golf ball in the air longer.
i: Force perpendicular to ball velocity, generated by backspin-induced pressure differential (Magnus effect): F_l = ½C_lρAv².

b: The physics behind how a spinning ball curves in flight, making draws, fades, and backspin-assisted lift possible.
i: Aerodynamic force on a spinning body due to asymmetric airflow. Creates lift from backspin and lateral force from sidespin.

b: Forces from air acting on the ball in flight, including both drag and lift.
i: Combined drag and lift forces on a body moving through air. Ball dimple pattern reduces drag by triggering turbulent boundary layer.

b: Force spread over an area, like the pressure distribution under your feet during a swing.
i: Force per unit area: P = F/A. In biomechanics, plantar pressure mapping reveals foot loading patterns during the golf swing.

b: The internal forces per unit area within a material, like the stress in a bone or tendon during loading.
i: Internal force per unit area (σ = F/A). Types: normal (tension/compression) and shear. Determines material failure risk.

b: How much a material deforms relative to its original size when forces are applied.
i: Relative deformation: ε = ΔL/L for normal strain, γ = tan(θ) for shear. Dimensionless measure of deformation.

b: A measure of how stiff a material is, determining how much it deforms under load.
i: Ratio of stress to strain in the elastic region: E = σ/ε. Cortical bone: ~17 GPa; tendon: ~1.5 GPa; muscle: ~0.01 GPa.

b: How much a material gets thinner when stretched, or wider when compressed.
i: Ratio of transverse to axial strain: ν = -ε_transverse/ε_axial. Ranges 0-0.5 for most materials. Rubber: ~0.5; bone: ~0.3.

b: Material behavior that combines elastic (spring-like) and viscous (fluid-like) properties, common in biological tissues.
i: Time-dependent mechanical behavior exhibiting both elastic recovery and viscous flow. Models: Maxwell, Voigt, standard linear solid.

b: The slow, continuous deformation of a material under constant load, like a ligament gradually stretching.
i: Time-dependent strain increase under constant stress. Biological tissues exhibit logarithmic creep. Relevant for prolonged loading analysis.

b: When the internal force in a material decreases over time while being held at a constant stretch.
i: Time-dependent stress decrease under constant strain. Exponential decay modeled by viscoelastic elements. Important in tissue loading analysis.

b: Energy lost as heat when a material is loaded and unloaded, visible as a loop on a stress-strain plot.
i: Difference between loading and unloading paths in the stress-strain curve. Represents energy dissipation. Tendons exhibit ~5-10% hysteresis.

b: Deformation that fully recovers when the force is removed, like a spring returning to its original shape.
i: Reversible deformation where material returns to original shape upon unloading. Governed by Hooke's law in the linear region.

b: Permanent deformation that remains after the force is removed, indicating material damage.
i: Irreversible deformation beyond the yield point. In biological tissues, indicates microstructural damage or failure initiation.

b: The stress level at which a material begins to permanently deform, marking the onset of damage.
i: Stress at the transition from elastic to plastic behavior. For cortical bone: ~130 MPa (compression), ~50 MPa (tension).

b: A force that acts sideways on a material, trying to slide one part past another.
i: Force acting parallel to a surface or cross-section. Important in joint loading analysis and cartilage mechanics.
